"'''Sing now, ye people of the Tower of Anor'''" is a proclamation uttered by a great [[Eagle]] to the people of [[Minas Tirith]], announcing the defeat of [[Sauron]] and the victory of the [[King Elessar|King]]. The Eagle came from the [[Lords of the West]] right after a wind had cleased the [[Dawnless Day|Shadow]] in the sky. The people in Minas Tirith was already filled with joy because of this, and answered the Eagle's words with songs in the streets.<ref>{{RK|VI5}}, p. 963</ref>

==Poem==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
Sing now, ye people of the Tower of Anor,
for the Realm of Sauron is ended for ever,
and the [[Barad-dûr|Dark Tower]] is thrown down.

Sing and rejoice, ye people of the Tower of Guard,
for your watch hath not been in vain,
and the [[Black Gate]] is broken,
and your [[Aragorn|King]] hath passed through,
and he is victorious.

Sing and be glad, all ye children of the West,
for your King shall come again,
and he shall dwell among you
all the days of your life.

And the [[White Tree of Gondor|Tree]] that was withered shall be renewed, 
and he shall plant it in the high places,
and the City shall be blessed.

Sing all ye people!
</poem>

==Inspiration==
[[Tom Shippey]] explains the clear inspiration of the poem from the Biblical style and language, specially the [[:Wikipedia:Psalms|Psalms]]. "''Sing and rejoice''" resembles the "''Rejoice in the Lord''" from [[:Wikipedia:Psalm 33|Psalm 33]], while the whole poem resembles [[:Wikipedia:Psalm 24|Psalm 24]]: "''Lift up your heads, O ye gates; and be ye lift up, ye everlasting doors; and the King of glory shall come in.''" The imagery is also reminiscent of the [[Christianity|Christian]] defeat upon the gates of hell and [[Christ]]'s coming.<ref>[[Tom Shippey]], ''[[The Road to Middle-earth]]'' (2nd ed.), pp. 180-181</ref>
